By Emily Warner

Emily Warner (she/her) reviews Heathers the Musical.

Fiona Shaw

<strong>Sian Turner</strong> talks to author and writing fellow at York, Fiona Shaw, about her newly released novel Tell It To The Bees.

The Homecoming

By plucking a glittering star out of the firmament, director Damian Cruden has had his hands burned.

A Winter's Tale

Given the infamous uncomfortable nature of the Drama Barn seats, staging a three hour Shakespearean tragic-comedy would seem a brave choice, especially following the influx of lighter comedies on this season at the Barn

Antonia Shaw

A macabre obsession with our own mortality and a general dystopian outlook are both prevalent fascinations in today's society.

The Government Inspector

The Russian play had all the promise of an excellent theatre experience - humour, mistaken identity and a wide and animated cast of 19 characters.

Mad about the musicals

Mad about the Musicals is currently one of the largest shows of its type touring the UK and they have finally arrived at York's Opera House.

Ken Dodd

There was once a time when comedian Ken Dodd was considered hilarious, however his stand-up routine is now as tired and incoherent as the eighty-one year old man himself.

Birmingham Royal Ballet

The Birmingham Royal Ballet's (BRB) annual British tour is always a treat - world class dancers performing on the intimacy of a York stage.

101 Ways to Pretend You're Not Forty

I was hopeful that the cast and crew of 101 Ways to Pretend You're Not Forty would prove their comedic talent once again. Happily, I was not disappointed.

Peter Dobbin

The Norman-Rea Gallery is trying something new.

St Mary's Installation, Five Sisters

<strong>Geoff Currie</strong> interviews the artists behind the St Mary's installation, Five Sisters.

The Art of Television

<strong>Beth Ridley</strong> speaks to television executive, producer, director and writer Tom Gutteridge, questioning TV as an art form.

The White Crow

Donald Freed's play portrays Adolf Eichmann's interrogation upon apprehension in Argentina.

Twelfth Night

Twelfth Night proves to have the same timeless qualities as Shakespeare's more exalted plays - with an added endearing sheen

Antonia Shaw

The latest production of J.M. Barrie's Peter Pan attests to our cultural infatuation with the accessible spectacular

Absent Friends

What is it about the Seventies, those beige and benighted years, that so appeals to the young directors of Dramasoc, and indeed to their audiences?

The History Boys

Witnessing a play's organic process, may seem like the average theatregoer's dream; but to witness this process is an unlucky opportunity, one which I had the misfortune to undertake.

Derren Brown: Enigma

Enigma: 'a mysterious or puzzling person or thing'.

Got Booty

Although I was slightly hesitant about a comedy production based entirely around the title "Got Booty" and had come prepared for the usual tirade of Tom Scott Pirate jokes, I was pleasantly surprised to find myself enchanted by the amusing randomness of the whole affair.

St Ives

St Ives, displays the unusual and unexpected modernist inspirations from a school of artists living in St Ives, Cornwall through the 1920s to the 1960s

Passing on the dreams; passing on the reality.

What is history if not the battle of ideologies? The History Boys, Alan Bennett's superbly timeless play examining the educational system and what it means to teach, inadvertently swerves into analogous territory.

The Jungle Book

Since the phenomenal success of the Lion King musical, it was perhaps inevitable that the Jungle Book would be hastily re-arranged for the theatre. However, it was never going to be easy to produce a stage production of a seminal text, blighted as it is by the fame of a wonderfully enjoyable, though factually awful, cartoon reproduction of Kipling's original.

Stones in his Pocket

Stones in his Pocket is a comedy written by Marie Jones, set in a rural town in County Kerry, Ireland. It concerns the invasion of this quiet place by an American production company who want to film their latest romance, 'The Quiet Valley', in an idealised Ireland.

The Pillowman

With a title as deceptively soft as the fictitious character which it describes, the audience might have been forgiven for expecting a whimsical, cheerful sort of performance from the cast of 'The Pillowman'. But as the posters plastered over the Barn doors pointed out, "there are no happy endings in real life"

Bawren Tavaziva

<strong>Harriet Waghorn </strong>talks to Zimbabwean dancer and choreographer Bawren Tavaziva.

Antonia Shaw

Antony Gormley, the man who sculpted the legendary Angel of the North and 1995 Turner Prize winner, has secured the coveted Fourth Plinth commission.

Dominique Gonzales-Foerster

The Unilever Series is back for 2009.

I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change

Billed as the first musical to be performed in the Drama Barn in "a very long time", hopes were high for this performance of the longest-running off-Broadway musical of all time.

Comedy Night 6

An eerie and expectant hush falls over audience as compere Nick Page took to the stage.

The Wonderful World of Dissocia

What followed, until the interval at least, was a colourful, imaginatively blocked and energetically performed ramble that was as cacophonously funny as it was, at times, grotesquely macabre
